channel.title: Need some startup advice
channel.description:
Hey Guys,
I'm wanting to get into electronics!
All I know at the moment is what I have learned in school, which regrettably is not much.
I do not wish to be spoon fed, or follow any tutorial word-for-word.
What I want is an idea of a simple project for me to start off with, and maybe a resource that could help with some of the terminology etc.
Cheers.

item.title: Need some startup advice
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

i’m sure anyone with any decent knowledge of electronics or computers wouldn’t waste their time working at maplin tbh. the staff at the store near me try to be helpful, but they’re pretty clueless considering where they work

Read full topic

item.title: Need some startup advice
item.dc:creator: @chri5 chri5
item.description:
@chri5 wrote:

Went to Maplin on the weekend, I needed to make a small switched lighting channels. A box, switch, wire, 2 resistors and LEDs was really all I needed. £25 for it all, joke. I would have bought it from the internet if I could wait another day…

Read full topic

item.title: Need some startup advice
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

^ he speaks the truth, however theres one on every high street, which is more than you can say for anyone else

Read full topic

item.title: Need some startup advice
item.dc:creator: @chri5 chri5
item.description:
@chri5 wrote:

Mopman:

maplin for ukfags obviously as well

Maplin sux, the staff are terrible and the prices are really terrible.

I’ve had good experiences with Farnell and Mouser.

Read full topic

item.title: Need some startup advice
item.dc:creator: @bootnecklad bootnecklad
item.description:
@bootnecklad wrote:

http://www.rapidonline.com/

All of the above are good too. Only posted rapid because no one else had. I don’t really have a specific site, I look around at multiple ones till I find the best deal for certain components. ie currently im buying parts for my cpu from an american site because the parts are $0.30 each, the parts over here are around £1.00. This can sometimes out way the import tax VATs etc etc

Read full topic

item.title: Need some startup advice
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

http://uk.rs-online.com

for europeans, couldn’t vouch for their quality its not the sort of stuff i need to buy, but my electronics teacher always seemed to carry their catalogue around and my dad uses them so i assume theyre not terrible

maplin for ukfags obviously as well

Read full topic

item.description:
@SETO wrote:

where can you buy resistors,op amps, capacitors or inductors,

not online, where i live (suberbs) no store has it

Read full topic

item.title: Need some startup advice
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

Get some kid-level electronics books, make a bunch of easy shit, etc – just get used to it and develop the right way of thinking about circuits.

Some ‘landmark’ projects might be building a simple AM receiver, a clock, whatever.
In my opinion, you ultimately want to work up to building really cool/useful shit with PIC/Atmega microcontrollers (Arduino is excellent for the latter), hackaday has a lot of Arduino projects and just generally interesting lower-level projects.

Read full topic

item.title: Need some startup advice
item.dc:creator: @bootnecklad bootnecklad
item.description:
@bootnecklad wrote:

Then enlarge the breadboard, get more leds some 74 series ICs and build yourself a simple computer!

Read full topic

item.title: Need some startup advice
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

Grab a breadboard, some LEDs and a 555 timer and make a blinking LED. Very basic, but a good start.

Read full topic
